author: KevinMarquette
body:
## PR Summary
add common aliases (`message`, `msg`) to Write-* commands default message parameter. This allows the user to rename `Write-Host` to `Write-Debug` or `Write-Verbose` to `Write-Information` without having to rename parameters (if they are specified). 

* add `Message` alias to the `MessageData` parameter for `Write-Information`
* add  `Msg` and `Message` alias to the `Object` parameter for `Write-Host`
* add tests that use Message and Msg aliases on Write-Information and Write-Host

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: I think that aliases should be added _only_ to solve some specific scenarios - what is the scenarios? In all other cases, this may cause problems now or in the future when it is necessary to remove these aliases and this will be an breaking change.

comments.author: KevinMarquette
comments.body:
I was trying to resolve some inconsistencies between similar commands. 

`Write-Information`, `Write-Verbose`, `Write-Debug` and `Write-Error` should have the same default parameter names so they are easily interchangeable. `Write-Host` and `Write-Output` could easily be argued to be part of this set.

One could make the argument that I took that too far with this change and I could dial it back to that specific scenario. I could exclude `Write-Output` and `Write-EventLog` to minimize the scope of this change.

comments.author: SteveL-MSFT
comments.body: @PowerShell/powershell-committee reviewed this and agree it makes sense for consistency for Message/Msg for Write-Host, Write-Verbose, Write-Warning, Write-Error, Write-Debug, Write-Information, but should not use `InputObject` as an alias nor change Write-Output nor Write-EventLog.
